video.title: Build a Shopping Cart with React and TypeScript - Tutorial
video.description:
Learn the fundamentals and how to build a ReactJS shopping cart with Typescript, Material UI, Styled Components and React-Query.

This tutorial uses a free open API for dummy data to the items in the shop. React-Query hooks is used for fetching the data from the API. 

Styled Components is used in combination with Material UI to customize the styles.

💻 Code: https://github.com/weibenfalk/react-shopping-cart

✏️ Course created by Thomas Weibenfalk. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnnnWy4UTYN258FfVGeXBbg

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Nein
topLevelComment.text:
Very nice. UseQuery is really handy. Im a bit confused on how we are not getting cyclic dependancy issues with App.js and Item.js, since they both export and import from eachother. Item.js using CartItemType from App.js, and App.js is using Item from Item.js. Trying to do this in node certainly would have created cyclic dependancy issues.

Anyone know?

replies.author: Mohammed Samir
replies.text:
@Ignacio Zullo
The bundler, e.g. webpack, will bundle all the package if the tree shaking is not working. Even if the tree shaking is working you will still have lots of garbage code.

replies.author: Ignacio Zullo
replies.text: @Mohammed Samir mmm no. I said import mui components like this import { Drawer, LinearProgress, ...  } from '@material-ui/core'

replies.author: Mohammed Samir
replies.text:
You will import all the available components, not the specific ones you need.
If there is not tree-shaking, you will make your bundle too huge.

topLevelComment.author: Constantine
topLevelComment.text: Hi. I want to ask about logic in programming. For example, I know about useState, useEffect etc. I understand what action, action creator, reducers, thunk creator, middleware are for, I partially understand promises and async await, but I have wild problems with logic. I know the syntax of these things, that if there is a request to the server, then use thunk, dispatches all of this, but the logic, what and how to write in the same reducer or AC..... is a complete mess.....just stupid sit there and have no ideas. I did by video, something, then I think I will not watch a new video, I will do it myself..... I do it and it does not work .... I watch the video, and there is not only 10 lines more code than mine, but it is only in one file, and the man in the video wrote code in three other files and it all worked, and I even had no thoughts about it. I'm sorry, I've made a mess here. But can you give me some advice on this?

replies.author: Naman Gupta
replies.text: I can recommend a thing or two. First of all, don't add/use any library/tool if it's not necessary. Keep it simple. If you are learning just go for simple things like for Global state management use PullState instead of Redux, Material UI and stuff like that. Once you get comfortable with those then move to more mature solutions like Redux, Redux Thunk etc. There is no such silver bullet. You can use any tool/library, first make it work then improve. Redux is famous because all big projects opt for that and they opt because the customization it provides is on the next level. You can use MobX. The simple reason I see here is you are just making it overcomplicated or your case falls under premature optimization. Let yourself bump into a problem. You will naturally see yourself hunting for a solution and realize why you need complex solutions. Last but not the least, Its okay and natural. Everyone feels this way.

replies.author: David Evans
replies.text: @Ben Kang Following along with this at the moment and was wondering the same. Thanks for clearing that up :)

replies.author: Ben Kang
replies.text: @Weibenfalk I'm assuming it's because he sees the console.log multiple times. I'm new to react-query, but I think this is working as intended. From the docs: "Out of the box, React Query is configured with aggressive but sane defaults. Sometimes these defaults can catch new users off guard or make learning/debugging difficult if they are unknown by the user. Query instances via useQuery or useInfiniteQuery by default consider cached data as stale..." So for those that want a traditional caching experience, they can set the staleTime to a higher value, thus considering the data non-stale.

replies.author: Weibenfalk
replies.text: Why do you think that? I'm using react-query and it caches the result. The API function itself is outside the App components so it won't be executed on each render

1. Re-use code, don't reinvent the wheel!
2. Re-use code, don't reinvent the wheel!
3. Re-use code, don't reinvent the wheel!
